posts.name: Anthony Baran
posts.cooked: I am at a competition right now and we are getting alternating, flashing green lights on CTRE Falcon 500 motors. When this happens we lose control of that motor. No were in the user manual do they explain this issue. I think its because the motors are drawing too much current and automatically shutting off control but I can’t prove this or find anyone who has solved this. Any help would be appreciated.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Hey @abaran7

The falcon 500 blink codes are documented in the V3 manual pages 39-43.

Blinking both green, both off, both green again, indicates “Forward throttle is applied. Blink rate is proportional to Duty Cycle”.

Alternating green is not documented.

I would suggest checking CAN wires for damage and looking at CAN bus health, utilization, etc…

posts.name: Anthony Baran
posts.cooked: We have checked the CAN bus and soldered all connections. This issue only occurs randomly when we are running the motors at higher percent outputs. It is not always the same motors that are affected, sometimes it is both drivetrain motors and other times it is one of our motors for a robot mechanism. When we run the mechanism and the drivetrain at the same time, then quickly switch buttons on the controller to another full speed mechanism, this issue can occur. So far there are four motors that we have tested that have had this issue happen to it. The only change we have made was changing the gearboxes from VEX to REV, which increased the gear ratios. The firmware version is 22.0 on both Talon SRX and Falcon 500s on our robot, since this is a non- FRC system for a college team and when the firmware versions are different between the Talon SRX and Falcon 500s, they don’t work.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Increasing gear ratios should mean less current is drawn at the motor to do the same work.

How are you commanding the motors? Are you using the classical PWM motor speed/direction control, or are you sending the motor controller commands over CAN ?

What’s your voltage bus look like during these transitions? How far down is the bus dipping or how high is it peaking when you start/stop motors and this issue occurs?

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: They are using falcons, if I remember correctly they can only be control using CAN

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: What firmware version are you running?

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
Screenshot_20240513_193337_Chrome 1080×251 40.5 KB From CTRE ’s offical Falcon500 page. Though I haven’t really seen this ever being used. Not sure why someone would prefer PWM over CAN .

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
PWM can be quicker than creating functional software, and used for motor testing or functional prototyping (many people did this with wooden shooter setups this year to great affect).

Additionally this OP is not using an FRC control system apparently. Trying to understand the control method then as it could be either.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: They mentioned that as 22.0 already in their original reply to me

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: Interesting, I didn’t know that, I haven’t seen any team use that

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
It sounds to me like a limit switch issue. According to the user manual , both the forward and reverse limit blink codes are the same. I suspect one is supposed to be green, which would be similar to what you’re seeing.

@ozrien can probably confirm.
